• Personal samplers and monitors are robust and ready for field-use. • Typical accuracy of personal samplers and monitors around ±30% • Combination of personal sampler and monitor may be the optimal choice. • Clear measurement strategy needed for assessing personal exposure

Exposure to airborne agents needs to be assessed in the personal breathing zone by the use of personal measurement equipment. Specific measurement devices for assessing personal exposure to airborne nanomaterials have only become available in the recent years. They can be differentiated into direct-reading personal monitors and personal samplers that collect the airborne nanomaterials for subsequent analyses. This article presents a review of the available personalmonitors and samplers and summarizes the available literature regarding their accuracy, comparability and field applicability. Due to the novelty of the instruments, the number of published studies is still relatively low.Where applicable, literature data is therefore complementedwith published and unpublished results from the recently finished nanoIndEx project. The presented data show that the samplers and monitors are robust and ready for field use with sufficient accuracy and comparability. However, several limitations apply, e.g. regarding the particle size range of the personalmonitors and their in general lower accuracy and comparability compared with their stationary counterparts. Keywords: Personal exposure Nanomaterials Personal sampler Personal monitor Exposure assessment

The decision whether a personal monitor or a personal sampler shall be preferred depends strongly on the question to tackle. In many cases, a combination of a personalmonitor and a personal sampler may be the best choice to obtain conclusive results.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The use of manufactured nanomaterials (MNMs) has increased at a constant pace over the recent years. Their applications range from scratch resistant surface coatings (Bauer et al., 2006) or lotus-leaf-like self-cleaning textiles (Liu et al., 2007), via building materials (Pacheco-Torgal and Jalali, 2011), energy applications (Arico et al., 2005) and enforced polymers, e.g. for dental applications (Hannig and Hannig, 2010), to enhanced cosmetics (Bowman et al., 2010). Besides the tremendous new opportunities offered by these novel materials, concerns have been raised because of potential adverse health effects that may arise if MNMs are taken up by the human body (Oberdörster, 2000; Simkó and Mattsson, 2010; Hoet et al., 2004; Gwinn and Vallyathan, 1818; Madl and Pinkerton, 2009). While human exposure to MNMs may in principle occur during any stage of the material's lifecycle (Hischier and Walser, 2012), it is most likely in workplaces where these materials are produced or handled in large quantities or over long periods of time (Kuhlbusch et al., 2011). Inhalation is considered as the most critical uptake route (Wiesner et al., 2006), because the small particles are able to penetrate deep into the lung and deposit in the gas exchange region. Inhalation exposure to airborne MNMs therefore needs to be assessed in view of worker protection.
Exposure to airborne agents can generally best be assessed by measuring the individual exposure in the personal breathing zone (PBZ) of an individual. The PBZ is defined as a 30 cm hemisphere around mouth and nose (EN, 2012). Measurements in the PBZ require instruments that are small and lightweight. The individual exposure specifically to MNMs has not been assessable in the past due to the lack of suitable personal samplers and/ormonitors. Instead, most studies related to exposure to MNMs have been carried out using either bulky static measurement equipment or not nanospecific personal samplers (Kuhlbusch et al., 2011; Brouwer et al., 2004). In recent years, novel samplers and monitors have been developed that allow for an assessment of the more nanospecific personal exposure to airborne MNMs. In the terminology used here, samplers are devices that collect particles onto a substrate, e.g. a filter or flat surface, for subsequent analysis, whereas monitors are real-time instruments that deliver information on the airborne concentrations with high time resolution. Only a few of these samplers and monitors are commercially available and are reviewed here regarding their comparability, accuracy and field usability. Where applicable, information from the scientific literature is accompanied with data obtained within the nanoIndEx project (project period June 1st, 2013–May 30th, 2016).
Besides personal samplers and monitors, (personal) exposure measurements require a clear strategy (Brouwer et al., 1867; Asbach et al., 2014). The exact strategy can vary depending on the local settings in the workplace and may need to be tailored to the questions to be tackled. The choice of instruments is affected by the measurement strategy. If, for example, task based exposure with short-lived spikes in the concentrations is to be assessed, the use of personal monitors with high time resolution is required. In contrast, for the determination of (e.g. shift-based) average concentrations, samplers may also be used. If personal exposure to a certain chemical species shall be assessed, thenwith the currently available technology, this can only be achieved by particle sampling and subsequent chemical analysis of the deposit. Placement of the instruments formonitoring of the backgroundor farfield concentrations is also an important component of the measurement strategy.

This article presents the state of the art in personal exposure assessment for nanomaterials. While the focus of this paper is on exposure to manufactured nanomaterials in workplaces, most findings are also directly applicable to the assessment of exposure to non-engineered nanoscale particles, e.g. in the environment (Asbach and Todea, 2016).

sections.heading: 2. Reviewofmeasurement and sampling techniques for personal exposure assessment
sections.text:
Personal exposure measurement requires the use of personal samplers and monitors (Koehler and Peters, 2015). The requirements for an instrument to be considered a personal monitor or sampler are a small size, low weight and a possibility for battery operation. The size and weight of a personal instrument should be small enough to be mounted directly within the PBZ of the individual. Alternatively, larger instruments can bemounted on a belt and sample from the PBZ through flexible tubes. The battery lifetime should ideally be ≥8 h, so that the instrument can be used for the duration of a full work shift.
Several prototype samplers (Azong-Wara et al., 2009; Azong-Wara et al., 2013; Furuuchi et al., 2010; Thongyen et al., 2015; Tsai et al., 2012; Zhou et al., 2014; Chen et al., 1999) and monitors (Wasisto et al., 2015; Qi et al., 2008; Liu and Chen, 2016; Li et al., 2009a) have been developed over the last years, however, only those that are commercially available and/or are used routinely are described here.

sections.heading: 2.1. Metrics issues
sections.text:
Currently,with very fewexceptions, no occupational exposure limits specifically for MNMs are available and instead the conventional mass concentration limits apply for chemicals and dusts. However, in this regard it is important to note that even if the number concentration is often dominated by nanoscale particles, such as MNMs, their mass is usually negligible compared to that of coarse particles. Consequently, other metrics than mass may need to be taken into account in order to make an adequate and comprehensive evaluation of exposures to MNMs inworkplaces. Unfortunately, it is not yet clearwhich key particulate parameters (mass, surface area, number concentration or their size distributions) could be the most relevant measurement unit with regard to MNM-related (occupational) health effects (Wittmaack, 2007; Rushton et al., 2010). While traditionally the particle mass concentration of airborne particles has been determined as exposure metric, other studies have shown that the particle number concentration (Peters et al., 1997) or the surface area concentration (Oberdörster, 2000; Driscoll, 1996; Schmid and Stoeger, 2016) may be better predictors for the health outcomes. However, Sager and Castranova (2009) reported that surface area alone may not be a sufficient health effect indicator, as in their study ultrafine titanium dioxide showed a higher bioactivity than carbon black for the same surface area dose. As of now, no instrument exists that is capable of measuring the geometric surface area of airborne particles. The only surface area related metric that can be determined for airborne particles is the so-called lung deposited surface area (LDSA) concentration, i.e. the fraction of the airborne surface area concentration that would deposit in the alveolar region of the human airways. To estimate the lung deposition, the physiological and breathing data for a reference worker are considered (Fissan et al., 2007). The LDSA concentration is measured by electrically charging aerosol particleswith a unipolar diffusion charger, followed by a measurement of the current induced by charged particles. The
chniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne 0.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049
measured current is directly proportional to the LDSA concentration. However, instrumental limitations apply to this metric (Asbach et al., 2009), as only the surface area of an envelope around the particle can be determined. Furthermore, a potential growth of hygroscopic particles in the humid respiratory tract, which affects the lung deposition rate, cannot be accounted for (Schmid and Stoeger, 2016). Themeasurements are therefore only accurate for non-hygroscopic, spherical or compact particles, whereas the internal surface of structured, i.e. agglomerated particles are not well represented. The measured currents can also be interpreted as being proportional to the active surface area concentration or the particle length concentration (Li et al., 2009b). Both concentration metrics were shown to correlate well with health outcomes in a panel study on health effects of ambient particles in susceptible populations (Rückerl et al., 2016). A newEuropean EN standard on the different metrics to be assessed in workplaces is currently under development under mandate M/461.
Personal monitoring instruments using electrical nanoparticle detection principles generally apply unipolar diffusion charging to determine LDSA (Fissan et al., 2007) concentrations and in some cases also the number concentration (Fierz et al., 2011; Marra et al., 2010). The number concentration can generally be determined more precisely with condensation particle counters (CPCs) (McMurry, 2000). However, as of now only a single commercial personal CPC exists (Ryan et al., 2015a).
Of the currently available commercial personal instruments, few aim at deriving mass concentrations. These include X-ray fluorescencebased mass determination of filter samples, which, however, can only be applied to nanoparticles of specific elemental composition signature before a particle background free of this signature element. Likewise, the mass of graphitic carbon-based MNMs may be quantified before the ubiquitous carbon-containing backgroundbyEC/OC analysis offilter samples. Knowledge of the background profile and composition is mandatory for the application of such techniques. The black carbon exposure may also be assessed by light absorption of filtered dust and aerosols. The particle background must thus always be studied before or after a work task assessment and, if possible, even in parallel by monitoring the supply air.

sections.heading: 2.2. Personal monitors
sections.text: Currently, five different monitors for measuring personal exposure to airbornenanomaterials are commercially available: (1) theMiniature Diffusion Size Classifier DiSCmini (Testo, Titisee-Neustadt, Germany, identical with miniDiSC) (Fierz et al., n.d.), (2) the Aerasense NanoTracer (oxility, Eindhoven, the Netherlands) (Marra et al., 2010), (3) the partector (naneos, Windisch, Switzerland) (Fierz et al., 2014), (4) the Personal Ultrafine Particle Counter (PUFP C100 and C200, Enmont, New Richmond, OH; USA) (Ryan et al., 2015b) and (5) the MicroAeth AE51 (AethLabs, San Francisco, CA, USA). While the first three instruments are based on diffusion charging of the nanoparticles, followed by the detection of currents on the femto-Amp level, the PUFP is a personal condensation particle counter (CPC) and the MicroAeth AE51 an aethalometer (Hansen et al., 1984). An overview of the available personal monitors and their specifications as provided by themanufacturers is given in Table 1.

sections.heading: 2.2.1. Personal monitors based on unipolar diffusion charging
sections.text:
All diffusion charging instruments, i.e. DiSCmini, NanoTracer and partector charge the particles and measure the particle induced current to derive the alveolar lung-deposited surface area (LDSA) concentration. The DiSCmini and the NanoTracer additionally also estimate particle number concentration and average particle diameter. In all three instruments, aerosols enter the instrument and are charged in a unipolar diffusion charger, where they acquire a charge which is nearly proportional to the particle diameter (q ~ dx, with x ≈ 1.1) (Jung and Kittelson, 2005), and, by coincidence, also nearly proportional to the
Please cite this article as: Asbach, C., et al., Review of measurement tec nanomaterials in workplaces, Sci Total Environ (2017), http://dx.doi.org/1
alveolar LDSA (Fissan et al., 2007; Asbach et al., 2009). The ion trap removes excess ions remaining after the charging process. The proportionality of particle charging to LDSA is not exact, but it can be thought of as a good approximation to LDSA at least in the size range of 20– 400 nm with a comparability and accuracy around ±30% (Asbach et al., 2009; Todea et al., 2015). Larger deviations occur outside of this size range. For micron-sized particles, the LDSA inferred from charging is about ten times too low, for very small particles around 10 nm, the determined LDSA is about twice as high as in reality. This over-estimation of small particles could be accounted for applying a higher voltage to the ion trap (Shin et al., 2007), however, none of the personal monitors realizes this concept. It should be noted that the contribution of sub20 nmparticles to the total LDSA concentration is typically low,whereas the deviation for large particles can be quite significant. Further uncertainties to the LDSA determination apply, such as differences due to particlematerial andmorphology (Fissan et al., 2012; Shin et al., 2010), and different breathing patterns of individuals (Jaques and Kim, 2000; Löndahl et al., 2007). There is also an uncertainty regarding the calibration of the instruments, because no standard on calibrating LDSA has been established as yet, and therefore instruments of differentmanufacturers may easily disagree systematically by 10–20%, due to different calibration routines.
2.2.1.1. Partector. The partector is the simplest and with a size of 13.4 mm × 7.8 mm × 2.9 mm the smallest of the available diffusion charging monitors. The unipolar charger is pulsed on-off so that clouds of charged particles are generated periodically (Fierz et al., 2014). These charge clouds pass through a Faraday cage connected to an electrometer, which reacts to the charged clouds by always keeping the entire cage electrically neutral. Hence, the charge on the Faraday cage is always the opposite of that inside the cage. By measuring the charge flowing to the cage, the charge on the aerosol particles can be inferred. The signal of the electrometer has a sinusoidal shape, and its peak-topeak value is a measure for the total charge on the particles, which is proportional to LDSA concentration. This type of charge measurement has the big advantage that electrometer zero offset drifts are automatically compensated for, and thus temperature/humidity variations hardly affect thedevice, and its start-up time is very short (16 s) compared to the others. The LDSA concentration is then measured with a time resolution of 1 s. An enhanced version of the partector is additionally equipped with an electrostatic precipitator that can collect particles onto a TEM grid for subsequent analysis.
2.2.1.2. DiSCmini. TheDiSCmini is the commercial counterpart of its original prototype miniDiSC. Except for some cosmetic changes, both are identical, so results from previous studies on miniDiSC are directly applicable to DiSCmini and vice versa. Both versions of the instrument will therefore be referred to as DiSCmini throughout this paper. Downstreamof the charger, theDiSCmini has two electrometer stages that are used to infer more information about the aerosol (Fierz et al., n.d.). Particles are charged continuously and detected first in a “diffusion stage” consisting of a stack of stainless steel grids, where preferentially smaller particles are deposited by diffusion. The larger particles have a higher probability of passing through this stage, and end up in a filter stage, where all remaining particles are collected. The sum of the currents from the two stages is proportional to the LDSA concentration. By measuring the ratio of the currents from the two electrometer stages, the average particle size is inferred. The particle number concentration is estimated from the total current and the particle size information, based on the assumption that particles are spherical and lognormally distributed with a geometric standard deviation of 1.9. The DiSCmini measures both currents in parallel, and thus estimates the LDSA concentration, particle number concentration, and mean particle size with a time resolution of 1 s. DiSCmini is the only instrument that uses a preseparator (impactor) that removes all incoming particles N700 nm (aerodynamic diameter). The particle size range for accurate LDSA
hniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne 0.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049
concentration measurements is limited to 20–400 nm (see above). For number concentration and mean particle size measurements, the lower size limit is not well defined. The unipolar charger exposes the aerosol to a low electric field strength, which can remove small charged particles. The instrument software is programmed to report no particle sizes smaller than 10 nm. The charging efficiency decreases with decreasingparticle size such that a very high concentrationmay beneeded in order to produce sufficient current. Since the number concentration determination relies on the unambiguous particle size measurement based on the currents from the two stages, the maximum particle size is approximately 300 nm, due to the onset of increased inertial particle deposition on the diffusion stage.
2.2.1.3. NanoTracer. The NanoTracer uses a unipolar diffusion charger, followed by a switched electrostatic precipitation zone to achieve essentially the samemeasurement capabilities as the DiSCminiwith a single electrometer detection stage, but with a lower time resolution (see Table 1) (Marra et al., 2010). The precipitator preferentially removes small particles from the gas stream, i.e. when it is turned on, the electrometer measures mostly large particles; when the precipitator is off, the electrometer measures all particles. As in the case of DiSCmini, the total current, measured when the precipitator is off, is proportional to the LDSA concentration and the average particle diameter is determined from the ratio of the two currents. Based on the assumption of spherical particles with a lognormal distribution with a user-definable geometric standard deviation, the particle number concentration is estimated. The latest version of the instrument, the NanoTracer XP, measures LDSA concentration, number concentration and mean particle size with a time resolution of 10 s in the advanced mode. The older versions of the NanoTracer have a time resolution of 16 s. All studies found in the literature and referenced below used the older NanoTracer versions. In fastmode, the precipitator is continuously switched off and amean particle diameter of 50 nm is assumed to determine the number concentration from the measured total current with a time resolution of 1 s.
2.2.2. Personal Ultrafine Particle Counter The Personal Ultrafine Particle Counter (PUFP models C100 and C200, Enmont, New Richmond, OH, USA) (Ryan et al., 2015a) is a water based condensation particle counter that determines particle number concentrations with 1 s time resolution. The incoming aerosol is exposed to an atmosphere, supersaturatedwithwater vapour. The vapour condenses onto the particle surfaces and makes them grow to optically detectable sizes. The lower cut-size is 4.5 nm. As in the case of most CPCs, the upper size limit is not well defined, but is likely in the range of a fewmicrometers, because these particles get lost in the internal sampling system because of inertia and/or gravitational settling. The water reservoir and battery last for up to 6 h continuous operation. The
Please cite this article as: Asbach, C., et al., Review of measurement te nanomaterials in workplaces, Sci Total Environ (2017), http://dx.doi.org/1
PUFP is equipped with a GPS receiver that tracks the position of its user and allows to link the exposure to the location (Asbach and Todea, 2016). However, this feature is intended for outdoor use and usually does not work for (indoor) workplace measurements.
Themodels C100 and C200 use essentially the same technology, but the model C200 is smaller, lighter and quieter than the C100.

sections.heading: 2.2.3. Black carbon monitor MicroAeth AE51
sections.text:
The black carbon monitor MicroAeth® (model AE51, Aethlabs, San Francisco, CA, USA) is a portable, self-contained and battery-powered aerosol monitor that uses airflow filtration and is capable of measuring Black Carbon (BC). According to the manufacturer (see Table 1) the instrument canmeasurewith a time resolution between 1 and 300 s.With typical ambient or workplace concentrations, the highest achievable time resolution to safely be above the noise level is usually around 1 min. The instrument uses real-time absorption measurements of a white, PTFE-coated borosilicate glass fibre filter. Optical absorption at 880 nm is interpreted as a real-time signature for the mass of black carbon particles on the filter. Quantification can be achieved by using the mass absorption coefficient for black carbon of 16.6 m2/g from the literature (Soto-García et al., 2011). The obtained result corresponds to an equivalent black carbon concentration. The MicroAeth® can be operated with an inlet cyclone with a cut-off diameter at 2.5 μm (PM2.5) at 50 ml/min flow rate and 1.4 μm (PM1.4) at 100 ml/min.
Any particleswith absorption at 880 nmdeviating from that of black carbon will cause incorrect mass predictions. It has been reported that the concentration of carbon nanofibres and -tubes can be determined with theMicroAeth®AE51 (Ogura, 2013; Hashimoto et al., 2013). However, the authors reported the response of theMicroAeth®AE51 to drop with increasing nanotube filter loading already at about 1/10 of the manufacturer's recommended filter load. In addition, nanotube-specific calibration was reported to be necessary.

sections.heading: 2.2.4. Accuracy and comparability of the personal monitors
sections.text:
In general, the accuracy and comparability of personal monitors can be studied under laboratory or field conditions. The latter can be further differentiated into studies, using ambient or workplace aerosols while the monitors are at rest and studies while the monitors are person-carried. Studies found in the literature mostly compare the results of the monitors at rest, while challenged with either well-controlled, lab-generated aerosols or ambient aerosols.
The comparability of the MicroAeth® AE51 monitor has been investigated in a few studies for ambient aerosols. Cheng and Lin (1853) compared the results of the AE51 obtained with ambient aerosols at a traffic site with those of a collocated stationary aethalometer and found very good correlations and agreement. Only when the filter got loaded, they observed a mismatch of up to 15%. Viana et al. (2015)
chniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne 0.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049
compared among others the Black Carbon (BC) concentrations measured with six MicroAeth® AE51 with those from a Thermo MultiAngle Absorption Photometer (MAAP). In addition they compared the results delivered by five DiSCmini with those from a condensation particle counter (TSImodel 3785) for thenumber concentration, a SMPS for the mean particle size and a nanoparticle surface area monitor (NSAM, TSI model 3550) for the lung deposited surface area concentration. In their study, they used ambient, urban air as test aerosol, while the instruments were static. The BC concentrations measured with the portable AE51 instruments agreed mostly within ±15% with those obtained from stationary instruments. The agreement of the mean number concentration from the five DiSCmini with the CPC data was mostly within ±20–30% with one DiSCmini delivering outliers that could be almost 50% off. A similar agreement was found for the LDSA concentrations measured with DiSCmini and NSAM, whereas the agreement of the mean particle diameters determined with DiSCmini and SMPS was slightly better.
DiSCmini and NanoTracer have been subject of a few laboratory intercomparison studies with well-defined test aerosols in the past (Asbach et al., 2012; Kaminski et al., 2013) that came to the conclusion that these instruments are in principle able tomeasure LDSA concentrations andmean particle sizeswith a comparability around±30%. Bau et al. (2015) confirmed this finding but also reported that particle number concentrations can be determined only with a lower comparability.
Studies on the accuracy and comparability of partector and the PUFP had been missing and were conducted within nanoIndEx. A laboratory study on the accuracy of the diffusion charging instruments (Todea et al., 2015) was carried out using monodisperse polystyrene latex (PSL), Di(2-ethylhexyl) sebacate (DEHS) or silver (Ag) particles in a size range from approximately 10 to 700 nm. The study confirmed that LDSA concentrations are measured by all three instrument types with an accuracy of ±30% as long as the particle sizes were within the range from 20 to 400 nm. The LDSA concentrations of particles smaller than 20 nm were overestimated, whereas the concentrations of particles larger than 400 nmwere underestimated as expected theoretically, because of the increasing slope of the LDSA per particle curve, which originates from the increasing inertial particle deposition in the lung. The results of this study are summarized in Fig. 1. The symbols in thefigure represent the arithmetic mean values of three DiSCmini, three partector and twoNanoTracer, respectively. Error bars indicate the standard deviations of the single one second data points. The measurement of number concentrations and mean particle size depend on the assumption of a lognormal particle size distribution with a certain geometric standard deviation and were hence found to be not meaningful with a monodisperse aerosol.
Two studies on the comparability of the personal monitors were conducted within nanoIndEx, one focusing on the diffusion chargerbased instruments (see paper by Todea et al. (2017) in this issue) and the other on the comparability of a PUFP C100 with other stationary CPCs (Asbach et al., 2017a). Both were conducted in a laboratory, using well-defined test aerosols.
The study on diffusion charging instruments included nine DiSCmini, seven NanoTracer and seven partector. A large variety of test aerosols with different particle sizes, concentrations, morphologies and materials were used in the study. The data from the monitors were compared with those from a Scanning Mobility Particle Sizer (SMPS) and an Ultrafine Condensation Particle Counter (CPC), which were used as reference instruments. The study confirmed that all diffusion charger instruments were able to measure LDSA concentrations and mean particle size with a comparability of ±30%. While the agreement averaged over all aerosols and instruments of the same type was better, the single one second data deviated mostly within ±30% with only a few outliers from the internal reference value. This range stems from different size distributions as well as from inter-specimen variability. This range applied to all particle size distributions which were mainly within the size range from 20 to 400 nm, independent of the total
Please cite this article as: Asbach, C., et al., Review of measurement tec nanomaterials in workplaces, Sci Total Environ (2017), http://dx.doi.org/1
concentration, particle material, and particle morphology. Only the NanoTracers from the very first instrument generation showed larger deviations. Like in the studywithmonodisperse particles, the LDSA concentrations were overestimated if the size distributions had significant fractions of particles b20 nm and underestimated in case of large fractions of particles N400 nm. The latter has also been observed by Mills et al. (2013). In agreement with the study by Bau et al. (2015), the results for the number concentrations showed a lower comparability with the CPC data. In the study by Viana et al. (2015) with ambient, urban aerosols the DiSCmini agreed well with the NSAM, although they consistently underestimated the LDSA concentrations between 7% and 13%, whereas the agreement of the number concentration with the data from the CPC was around ±20–30%. In contrast, Buonanno et al. (2014) reported that the number concentrations measured with six NanoTracers under stable laboratory conditions agreed within ±10%with condensation particle counters, whereas the comparability of the LDSA concentrations with reference data was within ±20%. Mills et al. (2013) reported that number concentrations of laboratory generated NaCl and metal particles measured by a DiSCmini agreed to within ±21% with the concentrations measured by a CPC. The differences in the comparability of the number concentration reported by Buonanno et al. (2014) and Mills et al. (2013) on the one side and Todea et al. (2017), Bau et al. (2015) and Viana et al. (2015) on the other side show that individual instruments may react very differently. In addition, other factors like particle shape and climatic conditions during the measurements can also play a role. However, none of the studies reported deviations of more than±30% for LDSA concentrations. Given the variability of the results, it is hence a safe assumption that the diffusion charging instruments measure LDSA concentrations with a comparability of ±30%, whereas number concentration measurements with these instruments depend strongly on the applicability of the assumptions on the particle size distributionsmade by the instruments. The comparability of the number concentration measurement can therefore be lower than for the LDSA concentration.
A second comparison study has been conducted within nanoIndEx to compare the results of a water-based PUFP C100 with four static CPCs (Asbach et al., 2017a). These four CPCs included a general purpose water based CPC (model 3787, TSI Inc., Shoreview,MN), a butanol based Ultrafine Particle Counter (model 3776, TSI Inc.), used as reference, and two N20 year old CPCs (model 3022 and model 3025A, both TSI Inc.). Hygroscopic NaCl, moderately hydrophobic carbon and highly hydrophobic DEHS particles with different polydisperse size distributions and concentrations were used. In spite of a few outliers, the one-second
hniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne 0.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049
data delivered by the PUFP C100 typically agreedwithin±10%with the reference CPC for NaCl and carbon particles as shown in Fig. 2. In contrast to the hydrophilic NaCl andmoderately hydrophobic carbon aerosol, highly hydrophobic DEHS particles weremore or less undetected by the PUFP C100. Similarly, also the stationary water based CPC (TSI model 3787) strongly underreported the DEHS concentrations. When impurities in the shape of isopropyl alcohol were added to the DEHS, the number concentrations measured with both water CPCs agreed much better with the reference CPC. The scatter plots in Fig. 2 for the DEHS aerosols show two branches each. The lower branches were always measured in the beginning whereas the higher branches were measured later during the experiments. The different levels of agreement likely stem from an increasing impurity of the DEHS over time.
For NaCl particles smaller than 25 nm, an increasing mismatch was observed, due to a decreased counting efficiency of the PUFP C100. The lower detection limit of the PUFP C100 is specified to be 4.5 nm. At this size, the instrument is designed to have a detection efficiency of 50%. The measurements showed that on the one hand the actual detection limit is close to the specified one, but on the other hand also that the detection efficiency does not increase steeplywith particle size. This is in principle comparable to the detection efficiency of handheld CPC (TSI model 3007) (Matson et al., 2010; Mordas et al., 2008). In summary, the PUFP C100 can be considered to be±10% accurate, as long as no very small particles, e.g. formed by nucleation, or highly hydrophobic particles are present. In indoor, ambient or workplace settings, such pure highly hydrophobic particles are rather rare, whereas already minor impurities make the particles detectable.

sections.heading: 2.3. Personal samplers
sections.text:
In contrast to direct-reading personal monitors, personal samplers are devices that collect particles for subsequent analysis. Typical substrates used in personal samplers are filters for the analysis of the mass concentrations and/or chemical composition of the particles, and flat surfaces (e.g. Si or GaAswafer) or TEMgrids for electronmicroscopic analysis of the particle size andmorphology or – if coupled with energy dispersive x-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (EDX) – the chemical composition. Typical particle collection mechanisms are filtration, electrostatic and thermophoretic sampling.
Measurement strategies that use sampling instruments and subject sampled aerosol ensembles to microscopic particle or fibre analysis
Please cite this article as: Asbach, C., et al., Review of measurement te nanomaterials in workplaces, Sci Total Environ (2017), http://dx.doi.org/1
can provide valuable information on this particle spectrumwith respect to number, size and morphology. However, missing agglomerate and particle densities together with a determination of only the 2Dprojected particle area currently limit the reliability of such indirect particle mass estimation.
The sampling of workplace atmospheres for such an individual particle-based analytical approach requires at least an approximate knowledge of the particle (number) concentration. The reason is that individual aerosol particle analysis does not tolerate too high coverage of the filter or substrate surface, which would lead to attaching or overlapping particles. In order to keep the coverage at an acceptable level, appropriate samplingdurationsmust be chosen based on prevalent particle concentrations. Such an approach is currently only applied by the partector TEM, which suggests sampling times based on measured LDSA concentrations. The ESPnano (Miller et al., 2010) is provided alongwith a list of optimal sampling times for given number concentrations. If not integrated in the instrument, the use of an additional monitor may be required to estimate the optimal sampling time, or multiple samples can be taken at different sampling durations. An overview of the technical specifications of the personal samplers is given in Table 2.

sections.heading: 2.3.1. Filter based samplers
sections.text:
A variety of filter-based personal samplers exist, typically consisting of a particle size-selective inlet, a filter cassette and a personal pump. Most of them are not nano-specific, but can still deliver valuable results, especially in cases, where the nanomaterial is of a specific chemical entity that otherwise does not occur in the workplace. In such cases, the filter can be digested and chemically analyzed, e.g. by inductively coupled plasma mass spectrometry (ICP-MS) to determine the mass concentration of this material. In other cases, filter based samplers are used to collect particles for electronmicroscopic (SEM or TEM) analyses to determine the presence of certain nanomaterials in the breathing zone. Conventional filter based samplers include among others the PGP (German: personengetragenes Gefahrstoff-Probenahmesystem, see Table 2) or the IOM sampler (SKC, Eighty Four, PA, USA).
2.3.1.1. NANOBADGE. The NANOBADGE (NANO INSPECT, Alcen group, Paris, France and French Alternative Energies and Atomic Energy Commission CEA, Grenoble, France) (Asbach et al., 2016a) is a personal filter based sampler, which can collect airborne particles directly in the PBZ of aworker. The sampler housing includes everything needed for the operation of the sampler, i.e. no additional pump is required. The sampler is connected to a cassette that is detached after sampling and sent to the service provider for analysis by X-ray fluorescence spectroscopy (XRF) providing a cumulative mass-based quantification of the chemical elements. The measurement of the engineered nanoparticle concentration by their constitutive element using XRF represents a powerful strategy for distinguishing the concentrations of a nanomaterial with a certain chemical composition from existing high and sometimes fluctuating background levels of natural and anthropogenic nanoparticles. Such a distinction is impossible with direct reading instruments (Kuhlbusch et al., 2011). Moreover, it is a non-destructive analytical technique, meaning that the same sample can be characterized further with other techniques such as scanning electron microscopy (SEM). The instrument is provided with filter units (single use) in individual zip bags and personal ID badge for personal use, i.e. one for each person operating the sampler. The filter unit is a sealed cassette containing a polycarbonate track-etched membrane to collect particles and is equipped with a RFID chip to store among others the sampling time, date, flow rate, worker ID, sample ID, etc. The NANOBADGE can be equipped with two different pre-separators to remove coarse particles (impactors for respirable fraction, i.e. with d50 = 4 μm or for PM2.5). A new service for providing quantification of carbon-based aerosols on quartz filters has just been introduced. Filters are analyzed in a thermal-optical analyser (Faure et al., 2014a) (Lab OC-EC Aerosol Analyser from Sunset Laboratory). Table 2 provides the technical specifications of the
chniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne 0.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049

NANOBADGE. The versions 2013 and 2015 are essentially identical, but the newer version operates at a higher flow rate than the previous version in order to collect more material and thus improve the level of detection.
2.3.1.2. Nanoparticle respiratory deposition (NRD) sampler. The personal nanoparticle respiratory deposition (NRD, Zefon International, Ocala, FL, USA) (Cena et al., 2011) samplerwas developed to selectively collect nanoparticles in a workplace atmosphere during full shift sampling. During the development phase, firstly a new collection criterion, namely the nanoparticulate matter (NPM), was devised in order to get the target collection efficiency of the sampler. TheNPM is the fraction of airborne particles that would deposit in the human respiratory tract by Brownian diffusion. In accordance with this criterion the NRD sampler selectively collects particles smaller than 300 nm, the diameter where for sub-micron particles the lung deposition curve shows a minimum. When inhaled, these particles can deposit anywhere in the respiratory tract.
The sampler consists of a respirable aluminum cyclone used to eliminate particles larger than 4 μm, followed by an impaction plate where particles larger than 300 nm are collected and a diffusion stage containing eight hydrophilic nylon mesh screens that collect particles with an efficiency matching the NPM criterion.
The particles collected on the nylon fibres of themesh screens can be characterized either by chemical analysis or by SEM to determine the size, number and chemical composition of the collected particles. Recently, an improved collection efficiency of stainless steel and welding fume particles has been reported, when the nylon mesh in the NRD sampler was replaced by a granular bed using glass beads (Park et al., 2015).

sections.heading: 2.3.2. Samplers for electron microscopic analysis
sections.text:
2.3.2.1. ESPnano. The commercial handheld electrostatic precipitator ESPnano model 100 is available from ESPnano, a division of Dash Connector Technology (Spokane, WA, USA) (Miller et al., 2010). This sampler is small and battery operated and collects airborne particles onto TEM grids. The sampler is mainly designed for workplace exposure assessment to prove the presence or absence of certain materials or particle morphologies e.g. in locations, where a release of particles is suspected.
The ESPnanomodel 100 uses a unipolar point-to-plate corona charger and precipitator to generate ions. When a positive high voltage is applied to a tip, a corona is formed that ionizes the air. In the ESPnano,
Please cite this article as: Asbach, C., et al., Review of measurement tec nanomaterials in workplaces, Sci Total Environ (2017), http://dx.doi.org/1
the tip electrode faces the sampling electrodewith the TEM grid. Consequently, the generated ions follow the electric field lines into the perpendicular aerosol flow, where they collide with the particles to charge them. The charged particles are deposited onto the TEM grid within the same electric field that is used to generate the ions and charge the particles. As the device is intended to be used under field conditions a removable “key” system was designed that would ensure a fast and easy replacement of the sample media between different samplings. The sample media can be pre-loaded in the lab onto the key and after sample collection the key can be kept in an airtight holder until the sample analyses are performed.
2.3.2.2. Partector TEM. The partector TEM (naneos particle solutions GmbH, Windisch, Switzerland) (Fierz et al., 2015) is an upgraded version of the personal monitor partector (see Table 1). The current measurement principle of the partector is based on induced currents, i.e. it does not require the particles to be deposited. The partector TEM therefore has a second stage following the current measurement, where the electrically charged particles are electrostatically collected onto a TEM grid. The partetcor TEM is the only instrument that combines a monitor and a sampler in one device and therefore is also the only one that suggests a sampling time for optimal TEMgrid coverage based on a concentrationmeasurement. TEMgrids can be pre-installed in screw-plug TEM holders that can be easily exchanged in the field.
2.3.2.3. Thermal Precipitator Sampler (TPS). The Thermal Precipitator Sampler (TPS, RJ Lee Group, Monroeville, PA, USA) collects nanoparticles onto standard TEM grids by exposing them to a thermal gradient in a narrowflow channel. Because of the temperature gradient, gasmolecules on the hotter side of the particle have greater kinetic energy than those on the colder side, transferring on average more net momentum upon collision to the particle than domolecules on the colder side, causing a thermophoretic particle motion towards the cold collection plate that includes the TEM grid. Similar thermal precipitators have already been used for decades for various applications (Azong-Wara et al., 2009; Azong-Wara et al., 2013; Kitto and Beadle, 1952; Holdsworth et al., 1954; Wang et al., 2012a; Jones and Warner, 1972; Broßell et al., 2013). The collected samples can be subjected to subsequent analysis of particle size, concentration and chemical composition (Thayer et al., 2011). A transfer function was developed that relates the number, size and composition of the collected particles to the ones of the test aerosol in order to reconstruct the particle number size distribution (Leith et al., 2014). A great advantage of thermophoretic particle collection over electrostatic sampling is that up to a size of approximately 300 nm,
hniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne 0.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049
the thermophoretic particle velocity is almost independent of particle size. The particle deposition onto the substrate is therefore homogenous and no function of particle size, which simplifies quantitative analysis.
The TPS samples aerosol at aflow rate between 1 and 10mL/min and utilizes a removable sample cartridge that holds the nickel TEM grid. The cartridge can be slid into the TPS body for sampling immediately below the hot plate while maintaining thermal contact with the cold plate to establish the thermophoresis zone. Because nickel is ferromagnetic, the grid is held in place by a small magnet located between the cold plate and the grid itself.

sections.heading: 2.3.3. Cascade impactors
sections.text:
In an impactor, the aerosol is accelerated in a nozzle and routed around a perpendicular impaction plate (Marple and Willeke, 1976; Marple, 2004). While small particles follow the flow streamlines, larger particles divert from the streamlines due their inertia and are collected on the impaction plate. An impactor is characterized by its cut-off diameter d50, i.e. the aerodynamic diameter, where 50% of the particles are collected. The cut-off diameter is determined by the nozzle diameter and the flow rate. A cascade impactor includes several sequential impactors with decreasing cut-off diameters to obtain size-fractionated samples for subsequent offline analysis. While large cascade impactors have been used for many decades already (May, 1945), only two personal cascade impactors exist that are able to also fractionate nanoparticles and/or their agglomerates.
2.3.3.1. miniMOUDI. The miniMOUDI (MSP Corp., St. Paul, MN, USA) is a miniaturized and personal version of the well-established Micro Orifice Uniform Deposit Impactor (MOUDI, MSP Corp.) (Marple et al., 1991). Different versions of the miniMOUDI exist with between six and 13 impaction stages, followed by a filter stage. All versions operate at a flow rate of 2 lpm. The version with 13 stages has four stages below 100 nm, the last one with a cut-off diameter of 10 nm, thus enabling the size fractionated sampling of true nanoparticles. Particles are collected on the impaction plates and can be used for subsequent electron-microscopic, chemical or other analyses.
2.3.3.2. Sioutas Cascade Impactor. The Sioutas Cascade Impactor (SKC, Eighty Four, PA, USA) (Misra et al., 2002) is a personal cascade impactor that operates at a flow rate of 9 lpm. The impactor has four impaction stages with cut-off diameters between 250 nm and 2.5 μm, followed by an after filter to collect all particles b250 nm.

sections.heading: 2.3.4. Accuracy and comparability of personal samplers
sections.text:
As of now, no studies on the comparability of personal nanoparticle samplers with each other have been published. Only studies, involving single samplers were conducted and are briefly summarized below.
2.3.4.1. NANOBADGE. The NANOBADGE 2013 was thoroughly studied in nanoIndEx. Its filters were analyzed by a calibrated (Motellier et al., 2011) X-ray fluorescence spectrometer (XRF) providing a cumulative mass-based quantification of the chemical elements present on the filters (Faure et al., 2014a; Faure et al., 2014b). The levels of detection (LOD) of the NANOBADGE along with XRF analysis were determined to be 30 ng/filter ± 20% for ZnO and 12 ng/filter ± 25% for TiO2 (Faure et al., 2017). The European Agency for Safety and Health at Work (EU-OSHA) distinguishes long- and short-term exposure, the former being a repeated exposure averaged over working shifts of 8 h and the latter a peak exposure averaged over 15 min (European Chemical Agency, 2012). The LOD for full shift (8 h) sampling is 0.1 μg/m3 ± 20% for ZnO and 0.04 μg/m3 ± 25% for TiO2. Both are several orders of magnitude below the latest recommended exposure levels (REL) of the National Institute for Occupational Safety and Health (NIOSH) (NIOSH, 2011) of 5000 μg/m3 for ZnO and 300 μg/m3 for TiO2. Therefore, the sampler could also be used for short-term exposure events (e.g. 15 min sampling).
Please cite this article as: Asbach, C., et al., Review of measurement te nanomaterials in workplaces, Sci Total Environ (2017), http://dx.doi.org/1
The results of the NANOBADGE have been compared to a scanning mobility particle sizer (SMPS) for ZnO test aerosols of three different modal diameters between 75 nm and 200 nm. The effective density and shape of the particles were determined experimentally using a tandem DMA-ELPI setup (Kelly and McMurry, 1992) to compare numberbased data obtained with the SMPS with mass-based data obtained with the NANOBADGE. The agreement between the SMPS and the NANOBADGE sampler was within ±25% for all test aerosols for which the effective density was determined.
2.3.4.2. NRD sampler. The NRD sampler has been thoroughly characterized by the developers (Cena et al., 2011). A NaCl aerosol was produced and the collection efficiency of the NRD sampler compared with the NPM criterion. Measurements were carried out using a SMPS and an aerodynamic particle sizer (APS). They found the impaction stage to have a cut-size (d50) at 295 nm, which is very close to the anticipated 300 nm. The deposition on the nylon screens was found to very closely match the NPM criterion for particles b100 nm, whereas minor deviations of up to 4% were observed for particle sizes of 200 nm and 500 nm. The collection efficiency did not change significantly with loading of the NRD sampler.
2.3.4.3. PGP-FAP. Within the nanoIndEx project, the PGP-FAP was used along with membrane filters for subsequent electron microscopic analysis, e.g. of collected nanofibres. The filtration efficiency of the membranes was estimated to be 99.8% by connecting a Nanometer Aerosol Sampler (NAS, TSI model 3089) (Dixkens and Fissan, 1999) downstream of the filter and evaluation by SEM. Collected particles were characterized, classified and counted with respect to their morphology. With a filter area of 707 mm2, in principle very low nanoparticle and fibre concentrations can be detected. However, high sensitivity requires mapping of a large part of the filter area withmicroscopic techniques of sufficiently high resolution. The microscopic resolution required to resolve, identify and count particles or fibres on a sampling substrate depends on their characteristic structure size. With decreasing structure size and pixel edge size however, the required number of pixels per area increases. The image pixel acquisition rate can thus practically impede the microscopic mapping of a sufficiently large filter area that is necessary to control an exposure limit for very thin nanofibres or small nanoparticles.
2.3.4.4. ESPnano. Miller et al. (2010) evaluated the performance of the ESPnano by producing polydisperse NaCl and/or KCl aerosols that were monitored with both a fast mobility particle sizer (FMPS) and a CPC. The gross collection efficiency was found to range from 76% to 94% for particle sizes between 30 nm and 400 nm. The findings were confirmed by SEM analysis of the collection substrate. In the nanoIndEx project, an ESPnano was used for a large number of laboratory and field studies and found to be a reliable sampler. Since the electrostatic deposition of charged particles relies on the particle size dependent electrical mobility, the deposit is not spatially homogenous. Data from the ESPnano were therefore mainly used for qualitative analyses, i.e. for the proof of the presence or absence of certain particle materials and/ or morphologies.
2.3.4.5. Thermal precipitator sampler (TPS). The collection efficiency and homogeneity of the deposit were analyzed for a prototype of the thermophoretic precipitator sampler (TPS) by Thayer et al. (2011). They found that the TPS samples 15 nm to 240 nm particles with nearly 100% efficiency onto its cold plate with a homogenous deposition pattern across the center of the plate, where a TEM grid can be installed. They also identified the need for correction factors to reconstruct the airborne particle number size distribution from the particle counts on the TEM grid. Leith et al. (2014) consequently developed a transfer function for the TPS for particle sizes between 20 nm and 600 nm, also taking into account particle losses inside
chniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne 0.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049
the device. The authors conclude that personal size distributionmeasurements can be done with the TPS along with the transfer function and that at a concentration of 50,000 #/cm3, 90 min sampling time would provide ample particles for analysis. However, no comparison of size distributions measured with TPS and particle sizing instrument (e.g. SMPS) is shown.
2.3.4.6. Sioutas cascade impactor. The Sioutas cascade impactor was originally called personal cascade impactor sampler (PCIS) and developed and evaluated by Misra et al. (2002). They evaluated different stages of the cascade impactor with polystyrene latex (PSL), ammonium sulfate and ammonium nitrate particles, using different impaction plate materials. The best results in terms of the sharpness of the collection efficiency were obtained with PTFE (Teflon) substrates with geometric standard deviations between 1.19 for the last stage (d50 = 2.5 μm) and 1.28 for the first stage (d50 = 250 nm). The experimentally determined cut sizes agreed with the design cut sizes between −8% and +4%. The mass concentrations of submicron ammonium nitrate particles collected with the PCIS were compared with those obtained from a static MOUDI (note that this was not the miniMOUDI described above) and a SMPS in multiple tests. The PCIS data agreed with the SMPS results within ±10% or better. Agreement with MOUDI results was poorer (the MOUDI showed significantly lower concentrations), which is assumed to be caused by volatilization of particles inside the MOUDI because of its high flow rate (30 lpm) and corresponding large pressure drop.

sections.heading: 2.4. Sampling tubes and pumps
sections.text:
Use of sampling tubes can introduce artifacts that bias the measurement. Particle losses are unavoidable during aerosol transport (Brockmann, 2011). These losses are mainly driven by particle diffusion (Gormley and Kennedy, 1949), sedimentation, inertial (Pui et al., 1987) and/or electrostatic deposition (Liu et al., 1985). Sampling tubes should hence be kept as short as possible. In order to avoid electrostatic particle losses, the tubes used should not generate or accumulate electrostatic charges or electric fields. This is best achieved by the use of electrically conductive tubing. For this purpose, carbon impregnated silicone tubes are very commonly considered as the optimal choice in aerosol measurements. However, it was found previously, that siloxanes might degas particularly from new silicone tubes (Timko et al., 2009). These siloxanes can be adsorbed by particles and alter their chemical composition (Yu et al., 2009). The use of such tubes should hence be avoided when using personal samplers for subsequent chemical analysis. Furthermore, the build-up of a silicon oxide deposit on the electrodes of a corona charger has been reported (Nashimoto, 1989) that may affect the charging efficiency (Fierz, 2016). In addition to the detrimental effect on the corona electrode,we found that siloxanes in the gas phase are preferentially ionized in corona chargers, like the ones used in DiSCmini, partector or NanoTracer, resulting in a decreased particle charging efficiency. We found that especially the DiSCmini significantly underreports the particle concentrations, when sampling through (new) conductive silicone tubes (Asbach et al., 2016b). The discrepancy can reach a factor of two or more in case of the DiSCmini, but is much lower for the partector. Tygon® tubes were found to be the best compromise between low measurement artifacts and good practicability.
During operation of personal samplers with cut-sizes in the nanometer range, it was furthermore found that the battery requirements for the personal pumps strongly increased. Prototype impactor samplers with cut-sizes at 100 nm, e.g. the ones described in (Furuuchi et al., 2010; Thongyen et al., 2015; Tsai et al., 2012) and used in nanoIndEx, caused a high pressure drop, which needs to be overcome by an increased pump power consumption. The sampling duration was therefore limited, due to a decreased battery lifetime. It should be noted that this did not apply to any of the commercial samplers listed in Table 2.
Please cite this article as: Asbach, C., et al., Review of measurement tec nanomaterials in workplaces, Sci Total Environ (2017), http://dx.doi.org/1

sections.heading: 3. Field applicability of personal samplers and monitors
sections.text:
Instruments intended to assess individual exposure of workers to MNMs in the field need to satisfy a number of specific requirements. Basic aspects address portability and include battery operation time, robustness and wearability during regular work as well as aspects of mechanical, electrical and explosion safety. Furthermore, the instruments have to produce reliable results not only under laboratory conditions, but also when carried by a person in the field. The usability of instruments for daily assessment depends predominantly on its weight and bulkiness. Since a minimum of 8 h battery life is necessary to collect data over a full work shift, battery capacity can be a significant weight and volume factor of portable instruments. Therefore, measurement principles with high-energy consumption may not be appropriate for personal application. As an example, current Li:Ion batteries have an energy density of approximately 200 Wh/kg. If the battery pack shall weigh no more than 100 g and last for 8 h operation, the instrument must not use N2.5 W. Only a limited number of field studies using the personal samplers and monitors have been published, these are summarized below and in Table 3.
Van Landuyt et al. (2014) usedDiSCmini instruments tomeasure the personal exposure of dentists to nanoscale particles during treatments of nanocomposite dental materials. They found that exposure concentrations can reach N106 #/cm3 during shaping restoration of a tooth. Cena et al. (2015) used NRD samplers to study the personal exposure of 44 welders to Cr, Mn and Ni particles. Due to the concept of the NRD sampler, they only looked at the amounts that would be deposited in the respiratory system and found large variations among the results, e.g. depending on the welding type employed. Asbach and Todea (2016) used a DiSCmini and a PUFP C100 tomeasure the personal exposure to ultrafine particles during a walking tour in Pisa. They found a good general agreement between the two instruments but also noted that the DiSCmini seemed to react quicker to changing concentrations than the PUFP C100. Consequently, the DiSCmini showed higher peak concentrations than the PUFP C100. Walser et al. (2012) determined the spatial distribution of nanoparticles upon simulated accidental nanoparticle release into a workplace using a distributed network of several stationary DiSCmini. Buonanno et al. (2013) used NanoTracers to determine the personal exposure of 24 non-smoking couples during everyday life activities in summer andwinter. They found that the average exposure levelswere higher duringwinter than during summer and that the exposure of womenwas higher compared tomen and concluded that the latter stemmed from differences in the cooking activities. Mazaheri et al. (2013) used NanoTracers to study the exposure of 137 Australian school children to ultrafine particles. They concluded that the majority (55.3%) of the daily alveolar doses result from exposure at home, whereas exposures at school amounted to an average of 35.5%. Meier et al. (2013) compared the response of a DiSCmini with that of a portable condensation particle counter (TSI P-Trak) during measurement of the exposure of highway maintenance workers in western Switzerland. They found good correlations between the results from the two instruments but found that concentrations reported by the DiSCmini were 30%–60% higher than those from the P-Trak, although both the number concentration andmean particle sizewerewell within the specified ranges of the instruments. It should, however, be noted that the P-Trak has been reported to underestimate ultrafine particle number concentrations because of a lower size detection limit of approximately 25–30 nm (Zhu et al., 2006). The observed discrepancy between DiSCmini and P-Trak may hence, at least in part, stem from different particle size ranges of the instruments. Dons et al. (2012) used a total of 13 MicroAeth AE51 to study the exposure of 62 individuals to Black Carbon (BC) at home and during N1500 trips using different means of transportation. They found the highest exposures for car drivers and car and bus passengers, whereas exposure to BC was 50% lower when traveling by bicycle or on foot. They generated approximately 125,000 data points, corresponding to about 10,000 h of data,
hniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne 0.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049
out of which around 4% were lost due to not further specified technical failures or human errors. Singh et al. (2003) carried out collocatedmeasurements with a Sioutas cascade impactor and a MOUDI, SMPS and APS, using ambient aerosol. They found that the agreement between the Sioutas impactor and the other instruments was typically within ±10%.
Fig. 3 shows a scatter plot of personal LDSA concentrationsmeasured with a partector vs. far field LDSA concentrations, determined from FMPS measurements. The data were obtained in a field measurement carried out in a pilot plant (Hülser et al., 2011) during the nanoIndEx project. Measurements were conducted during the production of Fedoped SiO2 particles, using a flame particle generator. The graph shows good agreement of the two measurement instruments during a side-by-side comparison (orange triangles). During personal measurements without any local source (blue circles), the personal partector measured LDSA concentrations very comparable to the far field concentrations, showing that on the onehand the aerosol in theworkplacewas homogenously distributed and mainly consisted of the background aerosol and on the other hand that the partector seems to have measured properly. Since the high safety standard of the pilot plant had been confirmed previously (Wang et al., 2012b), it was expected that no particles would be emitted during the production of the particles. Therefore, in order to mimic a leak in the production line as a strong
Please cite this article as: Asbach, C., et al., Review of measurement techniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne nanomaterials in workplaces, Sci Total Environ (2017), http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049
local particle source, an aerosol generator was used for approximately one hour to deliberately disperse NaCl particles into the workplace (green stars). In that case, the personal monitor showed much higher and more strongly fluctuating concentrations than the FMPS in the far field, showing that in the case of local sources, the individual exposure can only be determined by means of person-carried instruments, whereas static instruments can only reflect the exposure situation in one place.
None of the aforementioned studies reported any major obstacles regarding the field use of the instruments. This shows that the samplers andmonitors seem to be sufficiently robust to be used in the field. Field studies carried out in the nanoIndEx project led to the same conclusion. Themonitoredworkerswere asked to fill out a questionnaire, regarding the wearing comfort of the instruments, particularly if they felt disturbed. None of the workers complained seriously about the wearing comfort, although some responded that they felt a bit uncomfortable, because they could always feel that the instruments were there.
An effect that has not explicitly been considered in any of the aforementioned studies is that personal measurements can be biased by several influences, including personal activities, vibration, local airflows or relative velocities between the person carrying the instrument and the aerosol to be measured. Such effects have been observed in numerical studies (Salmandazeh et al., 2012) and during measurements of exposure to micron particles (Nilsson et al., 2016). In nanoIndEx, measurements of personal exposure to well controlled NaCl aerosols with modal diameters of 28 nm and 82 nm were conducted (Asbach et al., 2017b). During the measurements, an individual was inside a 23 m3 chamber, which was homogenously filled with the test aerosol. The individual carried two partector in the PBZ, one left and one right, while carrying out certain activities. A third partector measured inside the chamber, while resting on a table. No significant differences between the results obtained from the left and right side of the breathing zone were observed. The personal results also agreed within ±10% with those obtained by the instrument resting on the table. However, it was noted that the data showed higher fluctuations during activities like walking than during quiet sitting, but the average was unaffected. The same experiments were repeated after swapping the instruments left and right. In that case, the ratios reversed, i.e. the (small) differences stem from the instruments themselves, but not from the positioning of the instruments in the breathing zone. The study showed that wearing of the monitors as well as the positioning within the PBZ do not affect the measurement and hence personal exposure measurements using personal monitors can yield trustworthy results. It can be expected that these findings also apply to other monitors and samplers, at least as long as the sampling flow rates are similar. It should be noted that the aforementioned problems of using conductive silicone tubing were materializing in this study as well.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
The assessment of exposure to airborne nanomaterials requires the use of personalmeasurement or sampling equipment. Such personal instruments are still rather new and can generally be divided into personalmonitors and personal samplers. Personalmonitors are direct reading instruments and can provide the exposure concentrations in the PBZ with high time resolution. Personal samplers collect particles from the PBZ for subsequent chemical and/or morphological analysis. In order to be considered a personal sampler or monitor, an instrument has to be battery-operated and small and light enough to be carried by a person during the measurements. Downsizing of measurement instruments usually requires some compromises to be made, e.g. regarding accuracy, comparability, robustness, metrics that can be measured or the price. We have reviewed the available personal instrumentation and the corresponding literature regarding these compromises. Where appropriate, information on the performance of the samplers andmonitors obtained during the nanoIndEx project was added to the literature
Please cite this article as: Asbach, C., et al., Review of measurement tec nanomaterials in workplaces, Sci Total Environ (2017), http://dx.doi.org/1
review. A main compromise is a reduced wealth of information and lower accuracy than their stationary counterparts. The expected accuracy and comparability of LDSA concentration measurements is in the range of ±30% (Todea et al., 2015; Todea et al., 2017). A similar range has been reported for BC concentration measurements with a personal aethalometer (Viana et al., 2015). For number concentration measurements with diffusion chargers it can be lower (Bau et al., 2015; Todea et al., 2017).While the big advantage of personalmonitors and samplers are their small size and hence high mobility which facilitates personal exposuremeasurements, the accuracy and comparability of the personal monitors are certainly below those of conventional aerosol measurement equipment. Although the stationary instruments are more accurate in terms of concentration measurements, the fact that they are stationary means that they cannot provide accurate estimates of personal exposure. Hence, the reduced accuracy of personal monitoring devices in terms of measurement of particle concentrations is more than compensated by the fact that their results will better reflect the concentrations in the personal breathing zone, and hence will provide more accurate estimates of personal exposure than stationary devices. The only personal instrument that proved to have a better comparability was the personal condensation particle counter PUFP C100 (Enmont), at least for most aerosols. Number concentrations measured with the PUFP C100 agreed with stationary CPCs typically within ±10% or better (Asbach et al., 2017a). Only for highly hydrophobic particles, the PUFP C100 was almost blind. The instrument covers a broader size range than the diffusion chargers, but a smaller concentration range (see Table 1).
The comparability of the instruments was initially assessed by a literature review and in a laboratory study with all instruments at rest. However, a dedicated study on the effect ofwearing the instruments revealed that at least for nanosized particles, the results of the instruments are almost unaffected by thermal plumes, personal motion and moderate vibrations during personal measurements (Asbach et al., 2017b). On the other side it was noted that the choice of sampling tube materials can be very critical (Asbachet al., 2016b), especially in cases ofmeasurements with diffusion charging instruments. PVC (Tygon®) tubes were found to be the best compromise between practicability and the occurrence of measurement artifacts.
For the personal samplers it was noted that they usually operate at rather low flow rates. Depending on the analytical technique used for analyzing the sample, the collected materials may not be sufficient and below the LOD. In the particular case of exposure to carbon nanotubes, the effort for analysis of the substrates by SEMwas found to easily take several days in order to comply with the suggested exposure limit of 0.01 fibres/cm3.
There is no clear and simple answer to the question whether one should use a personal sampler or monitor for a personal exposure study. Of course, if exposure during short tasks shall be determined, only monitors with high time resolution can be used. Samplers might be used for 15 min sampling as long as the analytical techniques used to characterize and quantify the collected material have a sufficiently low limit of detection. If the goal is to produce shift averages, the use of samplers is also feasible. Another main question is the metric to be determined. Currently, the number and LDSA concentration can only be determinedwithmonitors (exception: sampling and electronmicroscopic analysis, but this is very time consuming),whereas themass concentration can only be determined with reasonable accuracy by using filter samples. If exposure to a specific chemical entity shall be determined, this can currently only be achieved by sampling and subsequent chemical analysis.
While monitors provide more (time resolved) information, this also means that more information needs to be analyzed, whereas the analysis of samplers directly provides a single valuewhich can bemore easily used in worker medical files or future epidemiological studies.
Workplace measurements generally present particle spectra of unknown composition. Individual MNM exposure assessment at
hniques and methods for assessing personal exposure to airborne 0.1016/j.scitotenv.2017.03.049
workplaces thus often requires a combination of monitoring and sampling instruments. Any exposure causes a particle type- and size-dependent dose. For a better distinction, not only particle number or mass concentrations are to be determined but the MNM dose must be differentiated by identity and origin. This requires morphological and chemical composition analysis of sampled particles by microscopy and X-ray (XRF, EDX), Raman spectroscopy or inductively coupled plasma mass spectroscopy (ICP-MS). This way information can be generated that is necessary to distinguish manufactured nanoparticles from those originating from natural or background sources like combustion and road traffic. A clear measurement strategy is hence required to conduct workplace exposure measurements. In order to answer the central question of sufficiency of risk management measures and to optimize the use of the available resources, quite often the use of a tiered approach (Asbach et al., 2014; VCI, 2011; Methner et al., 2009a, 2009b; Witschger et al., 2012; Ramachandran et al., 2011;OECD, 2015) is advisable. This means that in a first step the relevance of exposure assessment is checked by evaluating possible exposure using available documents and pre-knowledge of the workplaces in question (tier 1). If relevance cannot be denied, the second tier of exposure assessment will be necessary, which involves simple, fast and sufficiently reliable measurements. Personal monitors are especially useful in this context, although they are not explicitly included in the published approaches. The use of personal samplers with subsequent specific analysesmay increase the reliability of their results by helping to clearly identify the presence of the NOAA in question in the personal breathing zone. However, the decision criteria for moving from one tier to the next need to be well defined and documented. In any case, the management of the background concentrations in the workplace is crucial, which may necessitate the use of static instruments for monitoring background concentrations and/or the use of a combination of a personal monitor and a personal sampler to unambiguously distinguish between the nanomaterial of interest from particles of different chemical composition and/or morphology.

metadata.abstractText: • Personal samplers and monitors are robust and ready for field-use. • Typical accuracy of personal samplers and monitors around ±30% • Combination of personal sampler and monitor may be the optimal choice. • Clear measurement strategy needed for assessing personal exposure ⁎ Corresponding author.
